symptoms: small water-soaked dark spots on leaves
Pepper,_bell___Bacterial_spot.treatment: Remove infected leaves, avoid overhead irrigation, disinfect tools, and apply copper-based bactericides where recommended.

Pepper,_bell___healthy.treatment: Maintain regular watering, nutrition, and crop hygiene to keep plants healthy.

symptoms: small brown circular spots on lower leaves
Potato___Early_blight.treatment: Remove infected foliage, rotate crops, mulch soil, avoid overhead watering, and apply recommended fungicides (e.g., chlorothalonil) if needed.

symptoms: white fuzzy growth on leaf undersides
brown lesions on stems and tubers
Potato___Late_blight.treatment: Remove and destroy infected plants, avoid wet conditions, use certified seed tubers, and apply systemic fungicides when necessary.

Potato___healthy.treatment: Continue good agronomic practices; monitor regularly for pests and diseases.

Tomato___Bacterial_spot.cause: Bacterial infection often caused by Xanthomonas spp.
Tomato___Bacterial_spot.treatment: Remove infected tissue, avoid overhead irrigation, rotate crops, and apply copper-based treatments as advised locally.

Tomato___Early_blight.cause: Fungal disease caused by Alternaria solani (early blight).
Tomato___Early_blight.treatment: Remove lower infected leaves, practice crop rotation, improve air flow, and use fungicides such as mancozeb or chlorothalonil when needed.

symptoms: brown lesions on stems and fruit
Tomato___Late_blight.cause: Oomycete Phytophthora infestans (late blight), favored by cool wet weather.
Tomato___Late_blight.treatment: Destroy infected plants, minimize leaf wetness, and apply effective fungicides promptly.

symptoms: yellow patches on upper leaf surface
olive-green to brown mold on leaf undersides
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.cause: Fungal disease (Passalora fulva) favored by humid conditions.
Tomato___Leaf_Mold.treatment: Increase ventilation, avoid overhead watering, remove infected leaves, and apply appropriate fungicide if needed.

symptoms: many small circular spots with gray centers
heavy leaf drop starting from lower canopy
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.cause: Fungal pathogen Septoria lycopersici, thrives in wet conditions.
Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.treatment: Remove infected lower leaves, use mulch, improve spacing/airflow, and spray fungicides like chlorothalonil if required.

symptoms: tiny yellow or white speckling on leaves (stippling)
tiny moving mites visible on underside
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.cause: Infestation by two-spotted spider mite (Tetranychus urticae).
Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.treatment: Increase humidity, spray with water to dislodge mites, apply insecticidal soap or miticide, and remove heavily infested material.

symptoms: brown circular spots often with target rings
yellow halo or border around lesions
spots on stems and fruit in severe cases
Tomato___Target_Spot.treatment: Remove infected leaves, improve airflow and spacing, reduce moisture on foliage, and use recommended fungicides.

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.cause: Tobamovirus (Tomato mosaic virus) spread via tools, hands, or infected seed.
Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.treatment: Remove infected plants, disinfect tools and hands, use virus-free seed/stock, and practice strict sanitation.

symptoms: upward curling and yellowing of young leaves
often spread rapidly in a field
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.cause: Viral disease (Tomato yellow leaf curl virus) transmitted by whiteflies.
Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.treatment: Control whiteflies (yellow sticky traps, insecticides or natural predators), remove infected plants, and grow resistant varieties where available.

Tomato___healthy.treatment: Maintain balanced nutrition, irrigation, and routine pest monitoring to keep plants healthy.
